I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  committed  to  strengthening  governance, 
promoting  sustainable  private  sector  development,  and  encouraging  effective  financial  and 
corporate  disclosures  in  its  developing  member  countries  in  accordance  with  international 
standards and best practices. Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia, recognize the importance of 
good financial governance standards for enhancing their investment enabling climate, measured 
by a rising ratio of stock market capitalization to gross domestic product.1 Rational public and 
private investment decisions need accurate and timely disclosure of information relating to the 
financial condition of institutions. ADB and the three countries concur that enhancing their 
accounting standards in line with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs)2 and their 
auditing standards in line with International Standards of Auditing (ISAs) is necessary to achieve 
improved standards of financial disclosure and governance. 
  
2.  ADB approved in 2005 a regional policy and advisory technical assistance grant3 to help 
three Central Asian republics and Mongolia enhance financial disclosure standards. Specifically, 
the TA sought to improve accounting standards in the four countries in line with IFRSs and 
auditing standards in line with ISAs. The outputs of the TA were widely appreciated by all four 
countries as relevant to addressing capacity issues in the implementation of IFRSs and ISAs. 
Given (i) the basic structural similarity of the former Soviet Union (FSU) countries’ legal and 
regulatory framework for accounting and auditing and (ii) the wide appreciation of the outputs of 
the TA, the ADB staff assessment is that it could be replicated in Armenia, Azerbaijan, and 
Georgia  with  suitable  adjustments.  A  recent  ADB  mission  discussed  with  the  relevant 
stakeholders in Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia the scope of support needed.   
 
3.  Drawing on the experience gained and lessons learned from the earlier TA, the present 
TA4 will train accountants, auditors, and regulators to enforce more effectively accounting and 
auditing standards while fostering knowledge sharing in applying IFRSs and ISAs. Adopting an 
integrated  approach,  the  TA  will  identify  and  address  country-specific  weaknesses  in  the 
institutional, legal, and regulatory frameworks of Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia affecting the 
adoption of IFRSs and enforcement of ISAs. A regional approach under ADB’s aegis has the 
benefit of encouraging better interface, debate on the common problems, and the cost-effective 
sharing of experiences. The TA inputs will be used to develop country-specific action plans for 
strengthening financial disclosure standards in the three countries, allowing them to benefit from 
opportunities afforded by sharing experiences. The regional interface sought under the TA will 
complement,  not  substitute  for,  the  country-specific  focus  envisaged,  given  the  differing 
progress made by the three countries in accounting and auditing reforms. The TA’s design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Enacting  and  enforcing  transparent  financial  disclosure  standards  pose  particular 
challenges for the three countries, given the nascent state of their regulatory and jurisprudence

2   
systems  (Appendix  2).  Armenia,  Azerbaijan,  and  Georgia  nevertheless  recognize  the 
importance  of  sound,  uniform,  and  transparent  financial  disclosure  standards  to  provide 
comprehensive information about transactions and institutions undertaking them. The three 
contiguous countries face broadly similar problems in their accounting and auditing arenas 
attributable to their shared history. While their accounting and auditing sector reforms have 
been varied and their devolution asymmetrical, all three countries aim to have IFRS-compliant 
accounting and ISA-compliant audit laws.  
 
5.  Armenia’s accounting and auditing regulatory framework needs revamping for current 
relevance  (Appendix  2).  The  Republic  of  Armenia’s  Law  on  Accounting,  enacted  in  2000, 
mandates all legal entities to follow Accounting Standards of the Republic of Armenia. These 
are based on 2000 International Accounting Standards (IASs) and have not since been updated, 
thereby  creating  a  standards  gap.  This  gap  could  be  addressed  through  the  adoption  of 
legislation in line with the European Union’s 8th Directive (EU8D).5 The rule-based (rather than 
principle-based)  practical  application  of  the  Armenian  accounting  standards  has  rendered 
legally  disclosed  corporate  financial  information  perfunctory.  Only  financial  institutions6 are 
legally required to follow IFRSs by their regulators. This dichotomy renders comparisons of 
financial and other companies difficult. A more serious issue is the compliance gap when 
financial statements wrongly claim to have followed IFRS, thereby compromising their truth and 
fairness. The Republic of Armenia’s Law on Auditing mandates auditors’ compliance with 2000 
ISAs, which have not been updated. The two laws mandate the Ministry of Finance7 with 
licensing and supervising auditors and with monitoring corporate compliance with its accounting 
standards. Capacity constraints both in the Government and in the auditors’ profession make 
this task difficult. 
 
6.  Azerbaijan has pursued noteworthy accounting and auditing reforms in the recent past 
(Appendix 2). Azerbaijan’s Law on Accounting is moving towards IFRS compliance. Importantly, 
the law provides for the automatic incorporation of IFRS updates, without the need for fresh 
legislative approval, on the principle of EU8D, thereby addressing the standards gap. Further, 
the  law  mandates  the  Ministry  of  Finance  as  the  enforcer  of  accounting  standards  and 
particularly of companies’ publication of their financial statements and auditors’ opinions on their 
websites  and  local  media.  This  measure  supports  efforts  to  address  the  compliance  gap. 
Azerbaijan’s Law an Auditing Service has undergone, and is undergoing, amendments towards 
ISA compliance. Importantly, the regulation, licensing, and supervision of the auditing profession 
is mandated by the Law on Auditing Service to the Azerbaijan Chamber of Auditors (AZCOA), a 
self-regulatory  organization  (SRO)  and  an  IFAC  member.  AZCOA  nevertheless  remains 
answerable to the office of the President of Republic of Azerbaijan in the prudential discharge of 
its mandate. This maintains the right balance of autonomy with accountability for AZCOA. 
  
7.  More than its neighbors, Georgia needs significant reforms to its accounting and auditing 
regulatory infrastructure (Appendix 2). Georgia’s Law on Accounting, based on 1999 IASs, 
needs  updating  to  be  effective.  Enforcement  relies  on  the  Parliamentary  Commission  on 
Accounting, whose resource constraints have inhibited it from doing so effectively. Georgia’s 
accounting standards suffer from both the standards gap and the compliance gap. Georgia’s 
Law on Auditing, enacted in 1995, has since abolished mandatory audits of companies except

3
for listed ones and financial institutions. It has also abolished the licensing of auditors. Auditors 
may be certified either by the Georgia Federation of Professional Accountants and Auditors, an 
SRO with IFAC membership, or by the Audit Council, which is not an IFAC member. The 
former’s certification criteria is more stringent than the latter’s. This has created a divergence in 
the quality of certified accountants and auditors. As a result of the factors cited above, company 
financial statements and auditors’ reports cannot be relied on for rational investment or credit 
decisions.  A  new  consolidated  Law  on  Accounting  and  Auditing  was  drafted  in  2007.  Its 
enactment could help address these issues. The efficacy of the new law would depend on 
substantial training for Georgia’s accountants and auditors in the application of IFRSs and the 
enforcement of ISAs, which will be facilitated by this TA. 
  
8.  Some common generic constraints on the adoption of IFRSs and the enforcement of 
ISAs  were  observed  in  the  three  countries.  These  are  (i)  inadequate  knowledge  among 
supervisors, practicing accountants, and auditors of post-2003 IFRS and ISA developments and 
the IFAC’s professional ethics for lack of textbooks in the regional languages or opportunities for 
continuing professional education; (ii) the lack of normative guidelines for practicing accountants, 
auditors, and regulators in interpreting and implementing IFRSs and ISAs; and (iii) conflicts 
between the countries’ civil and tax codes and IFRS principles, which impinge on companies’ 
application of the latter (Appendix 2). 
 
9.  All  three  countries  have  benefited  from  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development technical assistance in this sector (Appendix 2). Azerbaijan also benefited from a 
World Bank loan approved in 2008 to strengthen corporate and public sector accountability. 
ADB’s interventions in the region thus far have been limited to a TA covering Azerbaijan along 
with the Central Asian republics.8 
 
10.  The  present  TA  will  concentrate  on  facilitating  the  implementation  and  regulatory 
enforcement of IFRSs and ISAs in the three countries. In doing so, it will complement and 
continue the efforts of ADB and other donors’ interventions (Appendix 2). This TA will help to 
address gaps in standards, compliance (para. 5), and differences in income recognition and 
asset valuation between IFRS principles and the countries’ tax codes. The outcome will be 
facilitated by (i) providing methodologies for addressing legal and regulatory impediments to the 
application  of  ISAs;  (ii)  training  regulators  on  the  updated  IFRSs  and  ISAs;  (iii)  providing 
methodologies for reconciling income and asset values computed according to IFRS standards 
and by local tax authorities; (iv) providing specific guidelines for interpreting and implementing 
ISAs; (v) recommending criteria for entry, such as examinations, and continued membership in 
the  profession;  (vi)  translating  accounting  and  auditing  textbooks,  ISA  and  IFAC  ethics 
guidelines, and other updated relevant material into the local language; (vii) establishing criteria 
for domestic audit firms’ audit of publicly listed companies and quality control of audits; and (viii) 
conducting,  after  the  completion  of  country-specific  domestic  training  programs,  a  regional 
seminar that will provide an interface for accountants, auditors, and regulators from the three 
countries to share their knowledge in applying IFRSs and ISAs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA impact will be to help improve governance in the corporate and financial sectors 
nationally and regionally. The TA outcome will be improved quality of accounting standards in 
Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia in line with IFRSs and auditing standards in line with ISAs. 
                                                 
8  ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for Regional Financial Sector Development. Manila (TA 6137-REG).

4   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The  TA  will  enhance  the  regulators’  capacity  for  setting  accounting  and  auditing 
standards and carrying out quality control, through both country-specific and regional training for 
regulators. Providing a common forum for participants to discuss and ameliorate their common 
generic constraints will foster better knowledge sharing among countries and thereby enhance 
regional cooperation. Drawing on this work, the TA will develop country-specific action plans to 
improve financial disclosure. Specifically, the TA will undertake the following activities.  
 
13.  Formulate guidelines for interpreting and implementing ISA. The TA will examine 
the countries’ audit laws and, where required, provide definitive and normative guidelines for 
interpreting and implementing ISA-compliant provisions of audit laws. 
  
14.  Build local ISA-compliant audit capacity. The TA will (i) facilitate the translation and 
publication  of  current  IFRSs,  ISAs,  and  other  relevant  material  (para.  10)  into  regional 
languages; (ii) research and analyze local audit firms’ audit capabilities in implementing IFRSs 
and  ISAs;  (iii)  recommend  minimum  qualifications  and  entry  requirements  for  the  auditing 
professions in the three countries; and (iv) establish criteria for domestic audit firms’ audit of 
publicly listed companies and quality control of audits. 
 
15.  Train regulators. The TA will train accountants, auditors, and regulators from the three 
countries in (i) the impartial application of IFRSs and ISAs, (ii) tax reconciliation procedures, and 
(iii) developing ISA-compliant audit interpretation and implementation guidelines. 
 
16.  Conduct a seminar as an interface for country participants. After completing the 
activities listed in paras. 13–15 within each country, the TA will organize a seminar to provide an 
interface  for  regulators  from  the  three  countries  to  share  knowledge  and  experience  in 
implementing IFRS and ISA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 equivalent. It will be financed on a grant basis by 
the  Investment  Climate  Facilitation  Fund9 under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration 
Financing  Partnership  Facility,  and  administered  by  ADB.  Detailed  cost  estimates  are  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will start in April 2009 and be completed by October 2009. ADB will be the 
Executing Agency for the TA. The Governance, Finance, and Trade Division of the Central and 
West  Asia  Department  will  administer  and  implement  the  TA  with  support  from  national 
regulators and other stakeholders. The Ministry of Finance of Armenia, Chamber of Auditors of 
Azerbaijan, and Georgia Federation of Professional Accountants and Auditors will be the TA 
implementing agencies (IAs).  
 
19.  The TA will require 24 person-months of consulting services between April and October 
2009.  The  international  consultant  will  be  the  team  leader  and  accountant.  The  national 
consultants will be accountants, one from each country. The four consultants will be assisted by 
counterpart  staff  from  the  three  countries’  IAs.  The  IAs’  counterpart  staff  will  guide  the

consultants’ research, facilitate access to relevant government and other agencies and officials, 
and provide necessary information. The three countries’ IAs will provide the team leader and the 
national consultants with office space, furniture, and a telephone line during TA implementation. 
An  international  consulting  firm  will  be  selected  using  quality-  and  cost-based  consultant 
selection10 and the biodata technical proposal method, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Selecting a firm for this purpose 
will facilitate better coordination between the team leader and the three national consultants in 
the three countries covered. Appendix 4 gives the outline terms of reference for consultants. 
Consultants will procure equipment in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, 
as amended from time to time).11  
 
20.  The team leader, with the help of the national consultants, will conduct training courses 
for practicing accountants, auditors, and regulators. The courses will be customized to fit the 
requirements of each country and are expected to be conducted in September 2009. A regional 
seminar will be conducted in October 2009 after the consultants complete their diagnostic and 
advisory work and domestic training. Resource speakers will be invited to add knowledge value 
to the regional seminar. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Enhancing  Financial  Disclosure  Standards  in 
Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 2   
ISSUES IN ARMENIAN, AZERBAIJANI, AND GEORGIAN FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE 
STANDARDS AND PROGRESS SINCE 2000 
A.  Background 
1.  For  Armenia,  Azerbaijan,  and  Georgia,  republics  of  the  former  Soviet  Union  (FSU) 
selected for this regional policy and advisory technical assistance (TA), adopting International 
Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs)1 and rigorously enforcing International Standards of 
Auditing (ISAs) present particular challenges, given the nascent stage of the development of 
their legal, regulatory, and jurisprudence systems and the different purposes accounting and 
auditing served in the days of central planning. The countries’ original accounting and auditing 
systems were designed to provide information necessary for operating a centrally planned 
economy. In this system, state agencies were the only users of accounting information. The 
prime function of accounting was to monitor and control the use of economic resources to meet 
planned  targets.  There  were  asymmetries  and  fragmentation  in  corporate  information 
disclosures and access to them that were vestiges of the Soviet era.2 This system of accounting 
differed substantially from IFRSs in (i) matching costs to revenues, (ii) valuing assets, (iii) 
computing the cost of production, (iv) its preference for legal form over substance as the basis 
for  presentation,  and  (v)  the  treatment  of  owners’  equity.  Auditing  in  a  centrally  planned 
economy  was  limited  to  an  inspection  function  where  compliance  with  regulations  took 
precedence  over  truth  and  fairness.  Since  enterprises  were  wholly  state-owned  and  their 
creditors  were  also  the  state  or  other  state-owned  enterprises,  the  need  for  independent 
financial control and reporting was never appreciated.  
 
2.  The  three  countries’  former,  inherited  accounting  and  auditing  systems  were 
inappropriate to the needs of a market economy toward which these countries were moving, 
albeit at varying speeds. Inevitably, the dichotomy created regulatory gray areas, which allowed 
financial  irregularities,  improprieties,  and  illegalities  in  the  three  countries’  enterprise  and 
financial  sectors.  These  infractions  were  undoubtedly  exacerbated  by  weak  economic 
management, poor governance structures, and weak legal and regulatory frameworks. Lack of 
transparency in financial disclosure was a serious detriment to investor confidence for the 
countries in transition. 
 
3.  Another major and congenital constraint on the creation of rigorous auditing standards 
has been the conflict between some IFRS and ISA principles on one hand and the three 
countries’ civil and tax codes on the other. In some instances, provisions of these laws have 
impeded  the  application  of  IFRSs  and  enforcement  of  ISAs,  particularly  in  areas  such  as 
depreciation accounting, the provision of gratuity and pension liabilities, and the valuation of 
foreign  exchange-denominated  assets  and  liabilities.  The  origins  of  this  conflict  may  be 
attributed to the three countries’ socialist civil law legacy, where provisions of the civil code 
overrode those of other statutes and, in socialist times, were not questioned by the courts. The 
goals of revenue collection are different from the needs of investors, which IFRSs and ISAs can 
satisfy. Moreover, as the ministries of finance (MOFs) or the tax committees spun off from them 
are also responsible for revenue collection, they have generally allowed the countries’ tax codes 
to override the provisions of their accountancy and audit laws where revenue collections were

International Accounting Standards Board of the International Federation of Accountants.

affected. Although differences between financial and tax reporting are common in developed 
countries, they are new to accountants and tax collectors in the three FSU countries. 
 
4.  Recognizing  the  importance  of  sound  and  rigorous  financial  standards  for  good 
governance, efficient financial intermediation, and sustainable growth, the three countries have 
taken  steps,  at  varying  speeds  and  with  the  help  of  development  partners,  to  adopt 
internationally accepted accounting and auditing standards, with some donor assistance. 
 
5.  Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia benefited from United States Agency for International 
Development (USAID) technical assistance to improve accounting and auditing systems (paras. 
6, 8, 10, and 20). Azerbaijan will benefit from a World Bank loan in this regard and from its 
participation in an earlier ADB TA. While seeking to create a critical mass of accountants with 
basic knowledge of IFRSs, and of auditors with ISAs, the countries need more assistance in 
applying this knowledge on a practical and functional basis. The following paragraphs describe 
the progress, issues, and challenges faced by each country. 
 
B.  Armenia 
 
6.  Armenia’s regulatory framework for accounting is the Republic of Armenia’s Law on 
Accounting  (RALOA),  enacted  in  2000.  RALOA  mandates  that  all  legal  entities  follow  the 
Accounting Standards of the Republic of Armenia (ASRAs). ASRAs are based on 1999 and 
2000 IASs. Companies may voluntarily prepare a parallel set of financial statements using 
IFRSs, but few do so. RALOA’s enactment and ASRAs’ creation through the translation of 1999 
and  2000  IASs  were  financed  and  supported  by  a  USAID  Accounting  Reform  TA  grant 
approved  in  1997.  ASRAs  themselves  have  been  declared  normative  bylaws  stipulated in 
RALOA.  In  addition,  all  enterprises  have  to  submit  their  financial  statements  to  the  tax 
inspectorate, whose requirements are different from ASRAs and IFRSs. 
 
7.  ASRA application has been based more on rules than on the principles that are the very 
rationale for IFRSs. As a result, the financial information disclosed by companies in Armenia 
remains perfunctory. ASRAs have not been updated since 2000, creating a standards gap in 
relation  to  2008  IFRSs.  Legally,  RALOA  does  not  allow  amendments  to  ASRAs  without 
reference to the legislature. This gap can be addressed by adopting legislation in line with the 
European Union’s 8th Directive (EU8D).3 Financial institutions4 are, however, required by their 
financial  regulators  to  prepare  their  financial  statements  in  accordance  with  IFRSs.  The 
Armenian financial sector has moved more quickly in establishing its compliance requirements 
with international norms than have other sectors. 
 
8.  The USAID Accounting Reform TA grant, approved in 1997, facilitated the establishment 
of the Association of Accountants and Auditors of Armenia (AAAA). It was USAID’s intention 
that AAAA become the professional self-regulatory organization (SRO) to regulate the country’s 
accounting and auditing professions. In pursuit of this goal, USAID approved a second TA grant 
in 2002 to strengthen AAAA. Under this TA, AAAA adopted, with the help of the Institute of 
Chartered Accountants of Scotland, the national accounting certification scheme syllabus of the 
Association of Certified Chartered Accountants of the United Kingdom. This certification scheme 
is  compliant  with  the  International  Education  Standards  of  the  International  Federation  of 
                                                 
3  The EU8D on Accounting and Auditing Standards was revised on 17 May 2006 and provides for harmonizing 
financial reporting standards by accountants and auditors in the European Union in accordance with IFRSs and 
ISAs. 
4  Comprising banks, insurance companies, mortgage companies, security trading companies, and pension funds.

12        Appendix 2   
Accountants (IFAC). In 2005, after a visit and comprehensive assessment by IFAC staff, IFAC 
made AAAA its associate member. 
 
9.  Notwithstanding  AAAA’s  progress,  RALOA  mandates  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and 
Economy (MOFE) as the supervisor and regulator of accounting standards in accordance with 
ASRAs. MOFE continues to certify and license accountants and auditors. It has limited capacity 
to enforce compliance with ASRAs, and even less with IFRSs. This has encouraged financial 
statements wrongly claiming to have followed IFRSs, thereby compromising on their truth and 
fairness.  
 
10.  As a follow-up to its earlier interventions, USAID in 2007 approved yet another TA grant 
for Financial Sector Deepening, whose activities began in June 2008. Under this TA, USAID 
finances the translation into Armenian of certain IFRSs relevant to the financial sector, IFRSs 1–
8  and  certain  guidelines  of  the  Standards  Interpretation  Committee  of  the  International 
Accounting  Standards  Board  (IASB).  After  the  acquisition  in  2007  of  the  Armenian  stock 
exchange by a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange, the demand for more transparent 
disclosures from listed companies will increase. The USAID project’s accounting component is 
an important link in this process. 
 
11.  The regulatory framework for auditing is provided by the Republic of Armenia’s Law on 
Auditing  (RALAD),  enacted  in  2001.  RALAD  requires  legal  entities  in  Armenia  to  follow 
International Standards of Auditing (ISAs) prevalent in 2000. There have been no updates to 
these  standards,  thereby  creating  a  standards  gap.  MOFE  licenses  auditors  who  obtain 
professional qualifications from it. MOFE’s examination and qualification criteria for accountants 
and auditors are reported to be at variance with IFAC guidelines. There is no requirement in 
RALAD for practicing auditors to undergo a minimum continuing professional education (CPE) 
annually to retain their licenses. A clear need exists to draw a regulatory boundary between 
MOFE and AAAA in the efficient and prudential regulation of the accounting and auditing 
professions.  While  Government  oversight  over  the  accounting  and  auditing  profession  is 
necessary, AAAA needs the operational autonomy to license and regulate auditors for quality 
control and professional integrity. These functions are currently exercised by the Ministry of 
Finance. 
 
12.  The important areas needing attention but not covered by USAID’s 2007 TA are 
(i)  translating into Armenian updates of ISAs; 
(ii)  translating into Armenian IFAC’s ethics guidelines; 
(iii)  developing training programs for regulatory and professional agencies (training 
the  trainers  and  regulators)  in  the  practical  application  of  IFRSs  and  the 
prudential enforcement of ISAs; 
(iv)  developing a proper mechanism for entry into and the retention of membership in 
the accounting and auditing professions; 
(v)  developing mechanisms for quality control of audits in accordance with ISAs; 
(vi)  preparing CPE curricula for accountants and auditors in accordance with IFRSs, 
ISAs, and international best practices; and 
(vii)  developing methodologies for reconciling IFRS-compliant financial statements 
with those required by the tax inspectorate. 
 
13.  Armenia will therefore benefit considerably from the ADB TA, which will specifically 
cover the areas above and thereby complement the current USAID TA.

Appendix 2  13   
C.  Azerbaijan 
 
14.  The World Bank’s Report on the Observance of Standards and Codes (ROSC) on 
Azerbaijan was published in September 2006. This document identified structural weaknesses 
in Azerbaijan’s accounting and auditing policy and regulatory infrastructure. Azerbaijan’s policy 
since 2007 in accepting and addressing those weaknesses is noteworthy.  
 
15.  Azerbaijan’s Law on Accounting (AZLOA) was enacted in September 2004. AZLOA 
mandates the Ministry of Finance (MOF) with responsibility for implementation. Initially, AZLOA 
required all companies in Azerbaijan to follow Azerbaijan National Standards (AZNASs), which 
were based on 1994 IASs. AZLOA was amended in 2007 (paras. 16–17 below). AZLOA now 
requires all financial institutions and public interest enterprises5 to follow 2008 IFRS standards in 
their financial disclosures. Azerbaijani subsidiaries of foreign companies are required to follow 
either IFRSs or the United States Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, depending on the 
country of incorporation of their holding companies. Other domestic companies are required to 
follow AZNASs. Recognizing the standards gap between AZNASs as they existed in 2007 and 
2007 IFRSs, MOF translated (with the permission of IASB and IFAC) into Azeri 36 IASs and 8 
IFRSs6  and, after obtaining the comments of the big four audit firms with offices in Azerbaijan, 
adopted 27 such standards through draft amendments to AZLOA.7 
 
16.  In a far-reaching decision, an amendment was enacted to AZLOA in 2007, providing 
under Article 6.02 for the automatic incorporation of future amendments into the law, and of 
future IFRS amendments and updated standards, directly into AZNASs without the need for 
fresh parliamentary approval for each standard or update separately. Based on the principle of 
the EU8D on Accounting and Auditing, this amendment addresses a major impediment to the 
standards gap.  
 
17.  For addressing the compliance gap and improving transparency in companies’ financial 
disclosures, Articles 12.3.1 and 12.3.2 of AZLOA, as amended in 2007, require every public 
interest enterprise and financial institution to publish its annual financial statements, and the 
auditors’ opinions thereon, on their websites and in the local media. These entities’ publications 
are required to state that their financial statements are published in accordance with IFRSs, as 
required by AZLOA. Other companies’ declarations are required to state unequivocally that their 
financial statements are in accordance with AZNASs, as is required by AZLOA. As MOF is 
responsible for executing and implementing all accounting standards under AZLOA, it is also 
responsible under the law for supervising and enforcing companies’ declarations. To reiterate 
this prudential function, a presidential decree was issued in December 2007 providing to MOF 
additional  powers  to  monitor  and  enforce  companies’  compliance  with  this  provision  and 
requiring  MOF  to  impose  penalties  on  companies  that  do  not  comply  with  this  statutory 
requirement. MOF will benefit substantially from this TA through the education and training of its 
staff in IFRSs to enable them to carry out MOF’s mandated role diligently.  
 
18.  Importantly, the Azerbaijan MOF’s Accounting Policy Office provided for the drafting of 
AZLOA. The Government of Azerbaijan engaged in policy dialogue with the World Bank under 
the policy loan (para. 20) and during the preparation of the ROSC, as well as with other

all financial institutions, public utilities, and other companies that provide public services. 
6   IASs 12, 29, 33, and 39–41 were not translated.

14        Appendix 2   
international audit firms, in the formulation of its amendments to its AZLOA and Azerbaijan’s 
Law on Auditing Service (AZLAS).   
 
19.  AZLAS was enacted in 1994, originally based on 1991 ISAs. It has since undergone 
several amendments and is due for major structural amendments in 2008. AZLAS provides for 
delegating  to  the  Azerbaijan  Chamber  of  Auditors  (AZCOA)  functions  in  the  areas  of  (i) 
conducting examinations,  (ii)  controlling  entry  into  the  auditing  profession,  (iii)  professional 
ethics,  (iv)  licensing  and  regulating  auditors,  (v)  quality  control  of  auditors,  (vi)  rights  and 
responsibilities of auditors, and (vii) auditors’ liabilities and disciplinary provisions. AZCOA is a 
professional accounting SRO established in 1996 and a full IFAC member. It receives no 
budgetary support. As an SRO, it is independent of MOF, which according to AZLAS exercises 
no power over AZCOA’s operations. Under AZLAS, MOF does not micromanage the auditing 
profession. AZCOA nevertheless remains answerable to the Office of the President of the 
Republic of Azerbaijan in the discharge of its legally mandated function. This arrangement 
maintains the right balance of autonomy with accountability.   
 
20.  The World Bank approved on 29 February 2008 a SDR7 million loan to Azerbaijan under 
the Corporate and Public Sector Accountability Project. The third component of this project, 
Strengthening  Accounting,  Auditing  and  Financial  Management  Capacity,  includes  (i) 
establishing  the  Azerbaijan  Center  for  Professional  Accounting,  Auditing,  Training,  and 
Research under MOF, with broad responsibility for strengthening Azerbaijan’s capacity; (ii) 
establishing  accounting  and  auditing  educational  standards  for  universities’  curricula  and 
helping  them  deliver  on  the  standards;  (iii)  establishing  benchmark  for  professionals;  (iv) 
developing an Azeri lexicon of accounting terminology; and (v) providing official translations of 
IFRSs. The World Bank loan partly addresses some of the challenges faced by Azerbaijan’s 
auditing  profession.  Azerbaijan’s  Central  Bank  received  USAID  technical  assistance  for 
enhancing financial institutions’ disclosures in accordance with IFRSs. 
 
21.  Azerbaijan participated in an ADB TA approved in 2003 for Regional Financial Sector 
Development.8 That TA focused on transparent financial disclosure and prudential financial 
regulation and supervision standards. Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, and Tajikistan 
participated  in  the  deliberations  of  this  TA.  The  TA  specifically  (i)  undertook  a  survey  of 
compliance with IFRSs by nonfinancial joint stock companies (NFJSCs), (ii) helped MOFs to 
begin  or  continue  implementing  IFRS  guidelines  based  on  best  international  practice,  (iii) 
identified some constraints to IFRS implementation in NFJSCs, (iv) conducted practical IFRS 
workshops for accountants from NFJSCs, and (v) conducted two regional training workshops on 
IFRS implementation for regulators and key participants in those countries. 
 
22.  To sustain the progress of its reforms undertaken thus far, Azerbaijan needs further 
assistance to (i) help MOF better exercise its mandate in enforcing companies’ publication of 
their  financial  standards  and  (ii)  help  AZCOA  with  the  challenges  faced  by  the  auditing 
profession by  (a) translating into Azeri updates of ISAs; (b) translating into Azeri IFAC’s ethics 
guidelines; (c) developing training programs for regulatory and professional agencies (training 
the trainers and regulators) in the practical application of IFRSs and prudential enforcement of 
ISAs; (d) developing proper mechanisms for entry into and the retention of membership in the 
accounting and auditing professions; (e) developing mechanisms for quality control of audits in 
accordance with ISAs; (f) preparing CPE curricula for accountants and auditors in accordance 
with IFRSs, ISAs, and international best practices; and (g) developing methodologies for the 
reconciling IFRS-compliant financial statements with those required by the tax inspectorate.

Appendix 2  15   
This TA can assist Azerbaijan in these endeavors. In so doing, it will cover those areas not 
specifically covered by other donors’ interventions and thereby complement them. 
 
D.  Georgia 
 
23.  The present state of regulation of the accounting and auditing professions in Georgia is 
in need of significant reform. There is no single agency responsible for either (i) the holistic and 
prudential  supervision  and  regulation  of  the  accounting  and  auditing  professions,  (ii)  the 
implementation of IFRSs, or (iii) the enforcement of ISAs. 
 
24.  The Georgia Law of Accounting (GLOA), enacted in 1999 with inputs from USAID TA 
approved in 1996, is outdated. Georgia’s existing accounting standards according to GLOA are 
based on 1999 IASs and do not correspond to IFRSs. According to GLOA, the Parliamentary 
Commission  on  Accounting  is  theoretically  responsible  for  approving  accounting  standards 
compliant with IFRSs. In practice, however, the commission has neither office nor budget to 
carry out its mandate. Under GLOA, only the commission is empowered to introduce normative 
legislation  to  incorporate  IFRS  standards,  but  it  has  been  unable  to  enforce  companies’ 
application of IFRSs. 
 
25.  The major impediments to the adoption of IFRS are (i) a standards gap, (ii) a compliance 
gap, and (iii) faulty IFRS-tax accounts reconciliation. The standards gap arose from the time lag 
between the introduction of an IFRS standard by IASB and its incorporation into Georgian law.  
 
26.  The compliance gap poses more serious problems. It arises from accountants’ lack of 
knowledge  of  IFRSs,  partly  because  of  their  conceptual problem  in  understanding  accrual 
accounting. It has resulted in them certifying financial statements as being IFRS compliant when 
they are not so in reality. This materially affects the truth and fairness of disclosures in such 
financial statements, which therefore cannot be used. Georgian financial statements deviate 
from IFRSs notably in (i) the consolidation of the accounts of affiliated companies; (ii) provisions 
for impairment of assets; (iii) related parities disclosure; and (iv) the valuation of property, plant, 
and equipment. They are therefore fundamentally different from parities followed under all 
recognized double-entry accrual accounting systems and can therefore not be relied on. At 
present only banks, insurance companies, and other financial companies follow near IFRSs. 
The country’s central bank regulates financial institutions’ compliance with banks’ adherence to 
IFRSs  and  ISAs.  The  State  Insurance  Supervision  Service  does  the  same  for  insurance 
companies. Even in banking and insurance companies’ financial statements, serious deviations 
from IFRSs have been reported.9 For nonfinancial undertakings, there is no single regulator 
responsible for the oversight of company financial statements. Other companies’ compliance 
with either IFRSs or even Georgia’s own outdated accounting standards therefore remains poor. 
 
27.  Georgia’s compliance gap is further exacerbated by the country’s tax requirements. Like 
in other FSU countries, Georgian tax law recognizes only cash-based accounting, and many 
companies prefer following cash-based accounting. The tax authorities have been unwilling to 
accept  IFRS-defined  income  for  taxation  or  offer  methodologies  for  reconciling  income 
according to tax legislation and IFRSs. 
 
28.  Auditing in Georgia is governed by the Law on Auditing, enacted in 1995. The licensing 
of auditors has been abolished. One SRO, the Georgia Federation of Professional Accountants 
and Auditors (GFPAA), is responsible for training accountants and auditors. GFPAA is the only 
                                                 
9  World Bank. 2007. Report on the Observance of Standards and Codes–Georgia. Washington, D.C. (January).

16        Appendix 2   
SRO in Georgia that is an IFAC member. GFPAA has translated some IFRSs and ISAs into 
Georgian. GFPAA is also responsible for the education of accountants and auditors and setting 
standards. GFPAA is, however, only one of the organizations that may certify auditors. For 
doing so, GFPAA requires candidates to undergo 3 years’ training to obtain a diploma, using the 
translated syllabus of the Association of Certified Chartered Accountants of London. Another 
agency in Georgia, the Audit Council, is also empowered to issue certificates to accountants, 
using much lower entry barriers. The Audit Council is a Soviet-era relic and not an IFAC 
member. This certifies a plethora of poorly qualified accountants and auditors practicing in 
Georgia. GFPAA can initiate disciplinary action against only its members and not against those 
certified by the Audit Council.  It is absolutely necessary to have rigorous quality control of 
auditors to ensure the high quality of audits. This can be facilitated only by ensuring that 
agencies certifying auditors are themselves professionally credible. Moreover, audits are no 
longer mandatory except for financial institutions and listed companies. Exemption encourages 
lax standards.  
 
29.  Unlike in the United States, with its Public Companies Accounting Oversight Board, or 
the  United  Kingdom,  with  its  Financial  Regulation  Council,  there  is  no  external  agency 
responsible  for  the  prudential  oversight  of  GFPAA  in  Georgia.  Georgia’s  accounting  and 
auditing oversight has not taken into account post Sarbanes-Oxley practices in other developed 
countries. In Germany, the United Kingdom, and the United States, however, it has been 
increasingly recognized in the past several years that the accounting and auditing professions 
need external oversight to avoid members’ possible conflict of interest from corporate and 
financial governance perspectives. This tautology, whose validity is recognized for developed 
countries, is even more relevant for transitional ones such as Georgia, where independent 
institutions are still not fully developed. External prudential oversight over the accounting and 
auditing professions is therefore of utmost importance. 
 
30.  A new consolidated law on accounting and auditing was drafted in 2007 but has not 
been approved by Parliament. The proposed law was intended to (i) provide for the application 
of  harmonized  and  IFRS-compliant  accounting  disclosure  standards  for  all  companies  in 
Georgia, except for small and medium-sized enterprises; (ii) facilitate the automatic import of 
IFRS updates into the proposed law based on the EU8D on Accounting and Auditing (which 
would allow for the seamless integration of Georgian accounting standards with IFRSs, without 
the need for legislative approval for each IFRS separately); and (iii) provide for regulating entry 
into  the  accounting  profession  by  raising  professional  entry  barriers  consistent  with  best 
international  practice.  Enactment  by  Parliament  could  significantly  improve  Georgia’s 
accounting and auditing regulatory infrastructure. 
 
31.  The current TA prepares for the enactment of the new law on accounting and auditing 
and can benefit Georgia by (i) educating accountants and auditor members of GFPAA in the 
application of IFRSs and the enforcement of ISAs; (ii) provide a methodology for reconciling 
IFRS financial statements with those required under domestic tax laws; and (iii) translating into 
Georgian the relevant IFRSs, ISAs, and other IFAC guidelines.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  An  international  firm  of  consultants  will  be  selected  using  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection1 and the biodata technical proposal method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). A team of one international 
consultant and three national consultants will be recruited to provide a total of 24 person-months 
of services, 6 international and 18 national, between April and October 2009. The international 
consultant will be the team leader and assume overall responsibility for the team’s output. The 
three national consultants will be accountants, one from each of the three countries. The firm 
will  nominate  the candidates,  both  international  and national,  and ADB  will  evaluate  them 
accordingly. Expertise and job requirements are in paras. 3–8 below. Consultants will procure 
equipment2 in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The four consultants will be assisted by counterpart staff provided by the implementing 
agencies  (IAs)  of  the  regional  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA).3 The  IAs’ 
counterpart staff will guide the consultants’ research, facilitate access to relevant government 
and other agencies and officials, and provide necessary information. The IAs will provide office 
space,  furniture,  and  a  telephone  line  to  the  international  and  national  consultants.  The 
consultants’ output will be subject to review and evaluation by the governments, IAs, and ADB.  
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
2.  Within 2 weeks of the start of their assignment, the three national consultants will submit 
inception reports to the team leader and simultaneously to ADB. The team leader will give ADB 
a comprehensive inception report consolidating the individual inception reports. Each inception 
report will contain detailed work plans to be undertaken by each consultant. The national 
consultants will submit monthly reports to the team leader. One month before the seminar, the 
national consultants will furnish the team leader with draft final reports on the assignments in 
each country. The team leader will submit to ADB and the governments a comprehensive and 
consolidated  draft  final  report  2  weeks  before  the  seminar,  and  the  final  report  after 
incorporating discussions and comments made at the seminar at TA completion. 
 
C.  Team Leader/International Consultant 
 
3.  The team leader will be a chartered accountant or certified public accountant who will be 
a member of an International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) member institute. The team 
leader will require knowledge and experience in (i) introducing International Financial Reporting 
Standards (IFRSs) and implementing International Standards of Auditing (ISAs) in transitional 
economies,  preferably  in  Armenia,  Azerbaijan,  and  Georgia;  (ii)  possible  areas  of  conflict 
between IFRSs and ISAs and the legal and regulatory infrastructure in Armenia, Azerbaijan, and 
Georgia,  as  well  as  proven  past  experience  in  addressing  them;  (iii)  capacity  building  for

D.  National Consultants 
5.  The three national consultants will be professional accountants from the three countries 
and will have had the experience stated in (i)–(ix) of para. 4 in their respective countries. They 
must have an excellent command of English. The possession in addition of law degrees would 
be preferred, as this would help them navigate more easily the domestic legal framework for 
applying IFRSs and enforcing ISAs. 
 
6.  The  three  national  consultants  will  be  engaged  for  a  combined  18  person-months 
between April and October 2009. They will be responsible for (i) assisting the team leader in (i)–

regional languages, (iii) assisting the team leader in conducting the domestic training workshops 
in their countries, and (iv) assisting the team leader in conducting the international seminar.

7.  In each country, a domestic training workshop for at least 20 accountants, auditors, and 
regulators  from  that  country  will  be  held  in  September  2009  after  the  national  consultant 
completes the diagnostic work. The workshop will be conducted by the team leader, who will be 
assisted by the national consultant.

held for regulators from the three countries for 5 days in October 2009. The seminar will be
